trans-unit.source: Network XHR Requests
Network requests in Kitchen Sink example
Never
Nevertheless, if you did want to write a test in Cypress, you already have the tools to do this without involving the UI.
Nevertheless, it is useful if your command can work in multiple ways - either with an existing subject or without one.
New “.scrollIntoView()”
New “.trigger()”
New “Catalog of Events”
New “Cypress.Commands”
New “Cypress.log”
New “Module API” doc
New “cy.scrollTo()”
New .scrollIntoView() command. Useful for scrolling an element into view. Fixes #498 & #313 & #519.
New cy.scrollTo() command. Useful for having a container scroll to a specific position. Fixes #497 & #313.
New .trigger() command. Useful for triggering arbitrary events. Fixes #406.
New Retryability doc #1278
New Code Coverage doc. Addressed in #1744.
New Visual Testing doc. Addressed in #1744.
New Courses doc to list online courses that teach end-to-end testing with Cypress. Addressed in #1766.
New Proxy Configuration doc. Addressed in #1486.
New Screenshot API doc
New cy.message and cy.msg commands in preparation for cypress-ruby, cypress-node, cypress-* packages/gem to talk directly to your back end.
New cy.task() doc
New Example CircleCI Orb
New chromium upgrade fixes situation where extremely long CI runs would sometimes randomly crash.
New chromium upgrade prevents synchronous XHR freezes.
New error message added about policy settings to our Error Messages doc. Addressed in #1567.
New kind of testing
New testing approaches not possible before
New traversal commands .nextAll(), .nextUntil(), .parentsUntil(), .prevAll(), and .prevUntil() have been added. Addresses #432.
New users to Cypress may initially find it challenging to work with the asynchronous nature of our APIs.
Newer CLI versions will not work on versions of Cypress < 0.19.0 (but we don’t know why this would ever even happen).
Next steps
No Args
No Arguments
No code changes to your server or client code
No guarantee your stubbed responses match the actual data the server sends
No longer force cy.visit() to navigate to about:blank prior to navigating to the real url. Fixes #208.
No longer send back a 500 message when initial response status code is 4xx.
No matches
No matter what is returned in the callback function, .each() will always yield the original array.
No need to use cypress-cli anymore to manage Cypress versions. You will need to uninstall the cypress-cli by running npm uninstall -g cypress-cli.
No need to use window.location
No test coverage on some server endpoints
No tests found in your file
No. You shouldn’t do that.
Node module dependencies updated. Fixes #1674 and #1942.
Noisy Promise demonstration. Not valid code.

None of the above commands are idempotent; they all cause side effects. Racing commands is not possible because commands must be run in a controlled, serial manner in order to create consistency. Because integration and e2e tests primarily mimic the actions of a real user, Cypress models its command execution model after a real user working step by step.
Normally Cypress would return the first <li> since that is the deepest element that contains “apples”.
Normally when the browser detects a cross-origin HTTP request, it will send an OPTIONS preflight check to ensure the server allows cross-origin requests, but cy.request() bypasses CORS entirely.
Normally when writing code in Node, you typically have to restart the process after changing any files.
Normally, as a user, all of your test code, your application, and Cypress commands are executed in the browser. But Cypress is also a Node process that plugins can use.
Not all config values can be changed at all times
Not all configuration values can be changed during runtime. See Notes below for details.
Not animating
Not as obvious where values come from versus the other options.
Not as useful if you’re using traditional server side HTML rendering
Not being covered
Not being disabled
Not being hidden
Not every command is retried
Not only is this an anti-pattern, but it’s an actual logical fallacy.
Not sure what a part of the URL a host is? Use this guide as a reference.
Not working for you? Don’t know how to set your token? If you still need to be able to be redirected to your SSO server, you can read about disabling web security.
Note that cy.clock() only applies to the top window on a web page. It will not override the time functions of any iframe embedded on the page.
Note that some implementations may rely on the input event instead, which is fired as a user moves the slider, but is not supported by some browsers.
Note that you must specify Date in order to override the current datetime. The example below just affects the current datetime without affecting scheduled timers.
Note the use of the standard function syntax. Using arrow functions to access aliases via this won’t work because of the lexical binding of this.
Note: we are still updating all of the docs to reflect all the 0.20.0 changes.

Note: we recommend deleting all files from the cypress/results folder before running this command, since each run will output new XML files. For example, we can add the npm script commands below to our package.json:
Notes
Nothing slows a test suite down like having to log in, but all the good parts of your application most likely require an authenticated user! Here are some tips.

Notice Cypress displays a message about this being the default page on the righthand side. Cypress assumes you’ll want to go out and visit a URL on the internet - but it can also work just fine without that.

Notice Cypress displays the message that it couldn’t find any tests. This is normal - we haven’t written any tests! Sometimes you’ll also see this message if there was an error parsing your test file. You can always open your Dev Tools to inspect the Console for any syntax or parsing errors that prevented Cypress from reading your tests.

Notice how the ADD_TODO action was executed 3 times - because our test has added 3 todo items, and the COMPLETE_TODO action was executed just once - because our test has marked 1 todo item as completed.
Notice it highlights in purple. This did three things worth noting…
Notice that the Cypress npm package is a wrapper around the Cypress binary. The version of the npm package determines the version of the binary downloaded.
Notice that this timeout has flowed down to all assertions and Cypress will now wait up to 10 seconds total for all of them to pass.

Notice that when adding up the spec’s run times (0:55), they add up to less than the total time for the run to complete (1:51) . There is extra time in the run for each spec: starting the browser, encoding and uploading the video to the dashboard, requesting the next spec to run.

Notice the calls to cov_18hmhptych.s[0]++ and cov_18hmhptych.s[1]++ that increment the statement counters. All counters and additional book-keeping information is stored in a single object attached to the browser’s window object. We can see the counters if we serve the instrumented folder instead of src and open the application.

Notice there is also a funny looking Log called: (PAGE LOAD) followed by another entry for (NEW URL). Neither of these was a command that we issued - rather Cypress itself will log out important events from your application when they occur. Notice these look different (they are gray and without a number).
Notification center
Now
Now Cypress provides us a UI (similar to debugger) to step forward through each command.
Now Cypress will skip its install phase once the npm module is installed.
Now What?
Now click on the home_page_spec.js file and watch Cypress open your browser.
Now if you remember at the end of the test we ended up on a different URL:
Now it’s time to write our first test. We’re going to:
Now let’s create our own spec file called home_page_spec.js.
Now let’s test out ** support.
Now let’s write our first failing test.

Now that we understand the real reason behind the flaky test, we need to think about why the default retry-ability has not helped us in this situation. Why hasn’t Cypress found the 2 <li> elements after the second one was added?
Now that we’ve got a page loaded, we need to take some action on it. Why don’t we click a link on the page? Sounds easy enough, let’s go look for one we like… how about type?

Now there is not even a need to do conditional testing since you are able to know ahead of time what campaign was sent. Yes, this may require server side updates, but you have to make an untestable app testable if you want to test it!
Now we can assert something about this new page!
Now we can put an .only on this test and it will run successfully irrespective of any other test. The ideal Cypress workflow is writing and iterating on a single test at a time.
Now we know exactly why our test failed. It had nothing to do with the DOM. Instead we can see that either our request never went out or a request went out to the wrong URL.
Now we’re in business! The first time through, cy.visit() and the cy.get() chain (with its .then() attached) are enqueued for Cypress to execute. The it block exits, and Cypress starts its work:
Now when Cypress logs cookies they will only include the name and value.

Now when you click the giant yellow failure messages if the error is a CypressError instead of logging nothing it will now find the command associated to that error and display the same message as if you clicked the failed command.
Now you can create parent, dual, and child commands using the same Cypress.Commands.add() command.
Now you can invoke the command from your project root like so:
Now you can omit the --key flag.
Now you can open Cypress from your project root one of the following ways:
Now you can select the error text in the GUI. Fixes #344.
Now you may be thinking, This sounds like a problem with Cypress because when I work with my application outside of Cypress it works just fine.ðŸ˜’
Now you should see a view explaining how to record your first run.
Now you’ll need to add in the following code in your test file to visit your server:

Now, by default, screenshots are nested within a folder with the name of the spec file that is currently running. Example - the spec named cypress/integration/foo/bar_spec.js will save screenshots inside of this directory: cypress/screenshots/foo/bar_spec.js/*. Fixes #1826.
Now, once you have your login completely tested - you may be tempted to think:
Nrwl Extensions for Angular
Number
Nx
OSX: ~/Library/Caches/Cypress
Object
Object of environment variables to set before the command executes (e.g. {USERNAME: 'johndoe'}). Will be merged with existing system environment variables
Objects
Obvious where environment variables come from.
Occurs after a screenshot is taken.
Occurs immediately before launching a browser.
Occurs in conjunction with the cy.task command.
Occurs when a spec or spec-related file needs to be transpiled for the browser.
Of course if the form’s submit event is preventedDefault the form will not actually be submitted.
Official Cypress Orb for CircleCI configuration.
Official TypeScript definitions for the Cypress API.
Official docs

Often a Cypress command has built-in assertions that will cause the command to be retried. For example, the .eq() command will be retried even without any attached assertions until it finds an element with the given index in the previously yielded list of elements.
Often times you may load a fixture in a beforeEach hook but want to utilize the values in your tests.

Oftentimes either the <i> or <span> element is covering the exact coordinate we’re attempting to interact with. In those cases, the event fires on the child. We even note this for you in the Command Log.
Oftentimes it can be much easier to programmatically control and boot your servers with a Node script.
Oftentimes it’s much simpler and conveys what you’re trying to test by just using .focus() directly.
Oftentimes it’s much simpler and conveys what you’re trying to test by just using .submit() directly.
Oftentimes we see users run into problems targeting their elements because:

Oftentimes we see users wanting the ability to use multiple reporters. When running in CI, you might want to generate a report for junit and perhaps a json report. This is great, but by setting this reporter you won’t receive any additional feedback while the tests are running!
Oftentimes you can use .trigger(), .invoke() or cy.wrap() to show the element before you perform the action.

Oftentimes your application may make initial requests immediately when it loads (such as authenticating a user). Cypress makes it possible to start your server and define routes before a cy.visit(). Upon the next visit, the server + routes will be instantly applied before your application loads.

Oftentimes, once you have a proper e2e test around logging in, there’s no reason to continue to cy.visit() the login and wait for the entire page to load all associated resources before running any other commands. Doing so can slow down our entire test suite.
Ok, now we want to click on the link we found. How do we do that? You could almost guess this one: just add a .click() command to the end of the previous command, like so:
Ok, we’re done talking. Now dive in and get started testing your app!

Okay but let’s say you’re worried about google.com serving up the right HTML content. How would you test that? Easy! Just make a cy.request() directly to it. cy.request() is NOT bound to CORS or same-origin policy.
Older CLI versions will continue to work on 0.19.0 except for the cypress open command - and will we print a warning to nudge you to upgrade.
Omit the fixture file’s extension
On Linux CI you should install the binary from the “Testing new linux x64 …” commit.

On Linux, Cypress scans your PATH for a number of different binary names. If the browser you are trying to use does not exist under one of the expected binary names, Cypress will not be able to find it.
On Mac, Cypress attempts to find installed browsers by their bundle identifier. If this does not succeed, it will fall back to the Linux browser detection method.
On Windows, Cypress scans the following locations to try to find each browser:
Onboarding dialogs will never show up again once they are dismissed. Fixes #522.

Once Cypress detects that a matching XHR has begun its request, it then switches over to the 2nd waiting period. This duration is configured by the responseTimeout option - which has a default of 20000 ms.
Once a GitHub repository is associated with a Cypress project, the GitHub integration will be immediately enabled:
Once again - we will need another reliable way to achieve this without involving the DOM.
Once multiple machines are available within your CI environment, you can pass the --parallel flag to have your tests run in parallel.
Once multiple machines are available within your CI environment, you can pass the --parallel key to cypress run to have your recorded tests parallelized.
Once that file is created, you should see it in the list of spec files.
Once the element is in focus, Cypress will begin firing keyboard events.

Once the tests finish, the coverage object can be serialized and saved to disk so that a human-friendly report can be generated. The collected coverage information can also be sent to external services and help during pull request reviews.

Once we’ve created that file, we should see the Cypress Test Runner immediately display it in the list of Integration Tests. Cypress monitors your spec files for any changes and automatically displays any changes.
Once you get the hang of async code you’ll realize you can do everything you could do synchronously, without your code doing any backflips.
Once you have a stub or a spy in hand, you can then create assertions about them.
Once you log in to the Dashboard Service you can view any public project.
Once you save again, you’ll see Cypress display the failing test in red since true does not equal false.
Once you save this file you should see the browser reload.
Once you set up your project to record, we generate a unique projectId for your project and automatically insert it into your cypress.json file.

Once you start a server with cy.server(), all requests will be controllable for the remainder of the test. When a new test runs, Cypress will restore the default behavior and remove all routing and stubbing. For a complete reference of the API and options, refer to the documentation for each command.
Once you’re set up to record test runs, we automatically generate a Record Key for the project.
Once you’ve enabled cy.clock() you can control time by ticking it ahead by milliseconds.

Once you’ve established it’s working you can then use stubs to test all of the edge cases and additional scenarios. There are no benefits to using real data in the vast majority of cases. We recommend that the vast majority of tests use stub data. They will be orders of magnitude faster, and much less complex.
Once you’ve read through the documentation below, we invite you to experience the power of Cypress reporters via Section 9 of our open source testing workshop for Cypress.
Once you’ve started the GitHub App installation process via a Cypress organization's settings or a project's settings, you will be directed to GitHub.com to complete the installation:
Once your server is running, it’s time to visit it.
One Superdomain per Test

One advantage of declaratively waiting for responses is that it decreases test flake. You can think of cy.wait() as a guard that indicates to Cypress when you expect a request to be made that matches a specific routing alias. This prevents the next commands from running until responses come back and it guards against situations where your requests are initially delayed.
One check per run group.
One common scenario Cypress supports is visiting a remote page and also preventing any Ajax requests from immediately going out.

One final question you should ask yourself is - is resetting the state even necessary? Remember, Cypress already automatically clears localStorage, cookies, sessions, etc before each test. Make sure you are not trying to clean up state that is already cleaned up by Cypress automatically.
One group can be called package/admin:

One last thing to consider here is that every once in a while we discover bugs in Cypress that lead to cross origin errors that can otherwise be fixed. If you think you’re experiencing a bug, come into our chat or open an issue.

One of the best parts of Cypress is its emphasis on debuggability. Unlike other testing tools - when your tests end - you are left with your working application at the exact point where your test finished.
One of the first (and arguably one of the hardest) hurdles you’ll have to overcome is testing logging into your application.
One of the first things many of our users attempt to do is involve 3rd party servers in their tests.
One thing you may notice though is that Cypress still enforces visiting a single superdomain with cy.visit(), but there is an issue open to change this restriction.
Only the first matched element will be returned
Only the last command is retried
Only valid when providing a --group or --parallel flag. Read our parallelization documentation to learn more.
Only works for values that should be the same on across all machines.
Open Cypress in detached mode
Open Cypress via cypress open
Open Source Plan
Open source
Open sourced another core repo: Cypress Core Test Runner which makes up the Cypress Desktop Application.
Open up cypress.json, which you will find in your project root (where you installed Cypress.) It starts out empty:
Open up Registry Editor by pressing WinKey+R and typing regedit.exe
Open up your Dev Tools and click on the GET for the .action-email class selector.
Open up your favorite IDE and add the code below to our sample_spec.js test file.
Open up your project in Cypress via cypress open.
Opening Cypress

Opening Cypress in global mode is useful if you have multiple nested projects but want to share a single global installation of Cypress. In this case you can add each nested project to the Cypress in global mode, thus giving you a nice UI to switch between them.
Opens the Cypress Test Runner in interactive mode.
Operating system version
Operating system version and browser version.
Operation system name
Opposite of .filter()
Opposite of .not()
Opt out of sending exception data to Cypress
Opt out on Linux or macOS
Opt out on Windows
Optimized first test run after hard refresh.
Optimized performance for hovering / exiting commands. Heavily reduced the CPU on revert / restore the DOM.
Optimized performance of command lists.
Option
Option #1: cypress.json
Option #2: cypress.env.json
Option #3: CYPRESS_*
Option #4: --env
Option #5: Plugins
Optional with Types
Options

Options passed to cypress open will automatically be applied to the project you open. These persist on all projects until you quit the Cypress Test Runner. These options will also override values in cypress.json.
Options:
Or Chrome Canary:
Or in the Given, When, Then syntax:
Or one check per spec file.
Or set record key as environment variable
Or via this.clock:
Organizations
Organizations are used to group projects and manage access to those projects.
Organize desktop vs mobile tests separately
Organize projects
Organized files around in preparation for OS release.
Organizing
Organizing Tests, Logging In, Controlling State
Orientation
Other Events
Other Library Utilities
Other commands have other default assertions not related to the DOM.
Other header edge cases fixed.
Other scenarios are fixed where command options would show incorrect number of object keys due to a bug in underscore’s reduce with an object that has a length key. Fixes #35.
Other than that, you’ll have to wait for us to implement APIs to support this (check our open issue), or you can disable web security.
Others, such as DOM based commands will automatically retry and wait for their corresponding elements to exist before failing.
Our “Node Modules” recipes show you how to modify the support file.
Our chat has now been directly integrated into Cypress’s nav. Clicking on the chat icon will immediately display the current gitter chat log.
Our algorithm should always be able to scroll until the element is not covered.
Our application correctly processing the response.
Our application inserting the results into the DOM.
Our application making a request to the correct URL.
Our build and testing processes have been upgraded to accommodate Linux builds.
Our internal proxy no longer strips HttpOnly cookie flags.
Our mission

Our mission is to build a thriving, open source ecosystem that enhances productivity, makes testing an enjoyable experience, and generates developer happiness. We hold ourselves accountable to champion a testing process that actually works.
Our mission, and what we believe in
Our official list of Cypress plugins.
Our run will generate files cypress/results/mochawesome.json, cypress/results/mochawesome_001.json, .... Then we can combine them using the mochawesome-merge utility.
Our team is always planning and working on really “big” upcoming features. Priorities can change as we move forward, but here is an outline of where Cypress is headed now.
Our test can confirm the property was properly set.
Our test should now display CONTAINS in the Command Log and still be green.
Our unit test is hitting the line we could not reach from the end-to-end tests, and if we execute all spec files - we will get 100% code coverage.
Our users are typically developers or QA engineers building web applications using modern JavaScript frameworks.
Output both the versions of the installed Cypress binary application and the npm module.
Output usage information
Outputs Key Events Table to console on click
Over in the Command Log you’ll see Cypress display the suite, the test and your first assertion (which should be passing in green).

Overhauled the entire subsystem dealing with an element’s visibility state. Previously we were using jQuery’s .is(":visible") selector which was ineffective at truly determining when an element is “visible”. Our changes now differ significantly from jQuery, but they match what a real user would consider visible, and the rules are fairly easy to explain. In other words these rules should just “make sense”.
Overkill for 1 or 2 environment variables.
Override url glob matching options
Override default Mocha timeout handling, replaced with custom logic. Removes many bizarre edge cases.
Override default port
Override the selectors that are returned per element
Overrides name only for display purposes.
Overrides the global requestTimeout for this request. Defaults to timeout.
Overrides the global responseTimeout for this request. Defaults to timeout.
Overriding Configuration
Overriding Options
Overview
Overview -
Overview:
Overwrite screenshot command
Overwrite visit command
Overwrite Existing Commands
Overwrites all other forms of setting env variables.
PR
PR comments and failure screenshot thumbnails are optional, and can be disabled if not needed within a project’s GitHub Integration settings:
Page Load Errors
Page Loads
Page Navigation
Page events
Page load events no longer forcibly null out the current subject. This was very unexpected and difficult to debug. Now stale elements or other objects from previous pages are yielded to you.
Pain to write the --env options everywhere you use Cypress.
Parallelization
Parallelization process
Parallelization settings
Parallelizing our tests across 2 machines saved us almost 50% of the total run time, and we can further decrease the build time by adding more machines.
Parent Commands
Parent commands always begin a new chain of commands. Even if you’ve chained it off of a previous command, parent commands will always start a new chain, and ignore previously yielded subjects.
Parse special characters for strings surrounded by {}, such as {esc}. Set to false to type the literal characters instead

Pass {animationDistanceThreshold: 20} to decrease the sensitivity of detecting if an element is animating. By increasing the threshold this enables your element to move farther on the page without causing Cypress to continuously retry.
Pass {force: true}. This disables all error checking
Pass {waitForAnimations: false} to disable animation error checking
Pass a function that can have any number of explicit assertions within it. Whatever was passed to the function is what is yielded.
Pass a function that expands the array into its arguments.
Pass a function that is invoked with the following arguments:
Pass a function that receives the arguments passed to the command.
Pass a function that takes the current yielded subject as its first argument.
Pass a function that takes the previously yielded subject as its first argument.
Pass a single string variable.
Pass an object as a JSON in a string.
Pass in an options object
Pass in an options object to Cypress.log().

Pass in an options object to change the default behavior of cy.route(). By default cy.route() inherits its options from cy.server().
Pass in an options object to change the default behavior of cy.scrollTo().
Pass in an options object to change the default behavior of cy.server(). These options are used for 2 different purposes:

Pass in an options object to define the implicit behavior of the custom command.
Pass in the CLI as `--env`
Pass only the host
Pass several variables using commas and no spaces. Numbers are automatically converted from strings.
Pass the command to boot your server, the url your server is hosted on and your Cypress test command.
Passes timeout through to .should() assertion
Passing .check({ force: true }) no longer requires the checkbox or radio to be visible. Fixes #1376.
Passing --headed will force Electron to be shown. This matches how you run Electron in interactive mode.
Passing --reporter can now reference an absolute path instead of just relative. Fixes #658.
Passing cy.route({stub: false}) or cy.server({stub: false}) is now deprecated.

Passing foo/bar/baz as the fileName arg to cy.screenshot() inside a spec, app.spec.js, will now result in the screenshot being saved to a nested folder path such as: cypress/screenshots/app.spec.js/foo/bar/baz.png. Fixes #1771 and #668.
Passing {force: true} to .blur() now logs correctly in the Command Log.
Passing a browser path containing spaces now works properly when passed to the --browser argument. Fixes #3979
Passing a function to .and() enables you to assert on the yielded subject. This gives you the opportunity to massage what you’d like to assert.
Passing a function to .should() enables you to make multiple assertions on the yielded subject. This also gives you the opportunity to massage what you’d like to assert on.
Passing an array of strings to ignoreTestFiles no longer causes an error to throw. Fixes #4312.
Passing cy.route({stub: false}) or cy.server({stub: false}) is now deprecated.
Passing multiple arguments to .its() now throws and suggests you use .invoke(). Fixes #147.
Password complexity requirements
Path to a specific project
Path to file to load before test files load. This file is compiled and bundled. (Pass false to disable)
Path to folder containing fixture files (Pass false to disable)
Path to folder containing integration test files
Path to folder where application files will attempt to be served from

Please be aware that Cypress only currently supports intercepting XMLHttpRequests. Requests using the Fetch API and other types of network requests like page loads and <script> tags will not be intercepted or visible in the Command Log. See #95 for more details and temporary workarounds.
Please check out our API docs for modifying configuration here.
Please note that .parent() only travels a single level up the DOM tree as opposed to the .parents() command.

Please note that .parents() travels multiple levels up the DOM tree as opposed to the .parent
() command which travels a single level up the DOM tree.
Please read our new documentation on writing custom commands.

Please read our Continuous Integration docs for help installing Cypress in CI. When running in linux you’ll need to install some system dependencies or you can just use our Docker images which have everything you need prebuilt.
Please read our Guide on Network Requests for a much more thorough analysis and approach to accomplishing this.
Please read our Best Practices guide on helping you target elements and prevent tests from breaking on CSS or JS changes.
Please read the .type() documentation for more details.
Please read this link in the Browserify preprocessor repo for instructions on modifying these.

Please refer to your code editor in TypeScript’s Editor Support doc and follow the instructions for your IDE to get TypeScript support and intelligent code completion configured in your developer environment before continuing. TypeScript support is built in for Visual Studio Code, Visual Studio, and WebStorm - all other editors require extra setup.
Please review grouping test runs documentation to learn more.
Please review our parallelization documentation to learn more.
Please review our grouping test runs documentation to learn more.
Plugin Types
Plugin files
Plugin for snapshot tests in Cypress. Same API as Jest, but with graphical interface for reviewing and approving changes.
Plugin that prints all browser console logs to the terminal while running Cypress tests. Currently, only Chrome is supported.
Plugin to save code coverage collected during Cypress tests
Plugins
Plugins API
Plugins Guide
Plugins are a “seam” for you to write your own custom code that executes during particular stages of the Cypress lifecycle.
Plugins can now return a Promise and modify the yielded config to set new configuration values and environment variables. Fixes #1042 and #909 and #576.
Plugins enable you to tap into the node process running outside of the browser.
Plugins enable you to tap into, modify, or extend the internal behavior of Cypress.
Plugins from our official list are just npm modules. This enables them to be versioned and updated separately without needing to update Cypress itself.

Plugins now emit a before:browser:launch event exposing you the browser that will be launched and its launch arguments. This enables you to modify the arguments prior to launching the browser. You can also use these arguments to modify how Chrome runs and to also test Chrome extensions. Fixes #691 and #298.
Plugins provide a way to support and extend the behavior of Cypress. Follow these instructions to submit your own plugin.
Port used to host Cypress. Normally this is a randomly generated port
Ported all links to use the new Cypress CDN.
Position
Position and dimensions (in pixels) used to crop the final screenshot image. Should have the following shape: { x: 0, y: 0, width: 100, height: 100 }
Pre-release binary URL format
Preferences
Prefixes
Preprocessors
Preprocessors API
Preserve Once
Preserve cookies through multiple tests
Preset
Prevent 3rd party windows from gaining focus over main window.
Prevent .pause() from actually pausing during cypress run.
Prevent cy.server() from slurping up Angular async template GETs.
Prevent cy.url() from accessing the URL during transition phase and throwing an error. Fixes #356.
Prevent Host header from having its port appended when request was for port 80 or 443 which lead to 3rd party reverse proxy problems such as with zeit.co hosting. Fixes #222.
Prevent NODE_ENV from being set to undefined when parent process did not have it defined. Fixes #1223.

Prevent undefined error when attempting to .click() an element which is fixed position when it is covered by another element. Cypress now correctly provides why it cannot click the element in question. Fixes #90.
Prevent XHR / Ajax requests before a remote page initially loads
Prevent XHR’s from throwing errors on arraybuffer content. Properly set xhr.responseBody for XML, blob, and arraybuffer.

Prevent a bug with node-sass on OSX + Windows when local node version does not match bundled node when importing components directly in spec files. The underlying issue was because we forgot to update Buildkite and Appveyor when we upgraded Electron in 2.0.0. Fixes #1387 and #1390.
Prevent accidental mutation of cy.server() options when cy.route() was provided options. Fixes #84 and #85.
Prevent app crashing when cypress.json could not be read or written to when adding a project.
Prevent cypress.app from showing in taskbar.
Prevent edge case where aliasing in the Command Log was aliasing the wrong command
Prevent error during element stringification on <svg>. Fixes #93.
Prevent error during verification in the CLI on Linux / OSX. Also makes terminal colors work again. Fixes #717 and #718.
Prevent error from being thrown when .only‘s are switched in between active test runs.
Prevent failed .should() and cy.to from outputting a second error’d command log.

Prevent fixtures from being accidentally overwritten and having their content blanked out. There was a very subtle chance due to node’s async file writing that as a file was being written with a formatted fixture, that another call to the same fixture would read in at that exact moment. If this happened the 2nd read would resolve with zero bytes, which would then end up rewriting the file back with zero bytes.
Prevent headless / CI from throwing errors on history.pushState and history.replaceState.

Prevent infinite loop due to a trifecta of rare circumstances with .click(). Clicking will now retry sync after it attempts to scroll past the element covering up the desired clickable element. Fixes #46.
Prevent infinite loop in edge cases when checking whether an element was hidden.
Prevent memory leak with Cypress helper listeners on every re-run of the tests.
Prevent memory leak with custom 3rd party Cypress listeners in spec windows on every re-run of the tests.
Prevent newer versions of Chrome from prompting you to save passwords and suppressed other extension related popups for Windows. Fixes #704.
Prevent passing {multiple: true} incorrectly showing up in Command Log. Fixes #88.
Prevent regression with not automatically scaling the viewport to fit into the window size
Prevent rejected promise from causing error about invalid API key during a CI run.
Prevent removing trailing new lines on fixtures after formatting.
Prevent reverting the DOM while tests are running. Fixes #28.
Prevent server from opening and immediately closing + re-opening when project is missing a Project ID and one is generated.
Prevented accidentally setting domain cookies when they were really hostOnly cookies, thus duplicating the number of cookies sent on requests. Kudos to @bahmutov for finding this one. Fixes #207.
Prevented bug where the assertion message: expected <x> element to exist would log over and over again when Cypress retried querying for a DOM element.
Prevented edge case with cy.fixture() where it would not be able to be canceled without throwing an unhandled rejection error.
Prevented external NODE_ENV mutations causing problems in CI.
Preventing mousedown does not prevent typing
Preventing default action on mousedown will no longer give focus as per the spec.

Previously Cypress would send the auth header to any URLs that match the CORS origin of the original auth header. We now correctly only send the auth headers when there is an exact match on the protection space. Fixes #4267.
Previously to record runs you had the environment variable: CYPRESS_CI_KEY or you wrote:
Previously using eventually.have.length was impossible (and this would throw an error), but now this works as you’d expect with the default should('have.length').

Previously we instrumented the application code (either using a build step or inserting a plugin into the Babel pipeline). In the example above, we are NOT loading an application, instead we are only running the test files by themselves.

Previously, we auto-magically included all files within cypress/support. This has now gone away and we’ve simplified this to automatically including a single cypress/support/index.js file. That single file acts as the entry point meaning you should import or require the other support files you’d like to include. Although this is still “automatic” it’s much less magical and we’ll be updating all of our docs to reflect this. The purpose of cypress/support hasn’t really changed, just the implementation of it has. We will automatically seed a cypress/support/index.js file for you (even on existing projects). The file location of cypress/support/index.js can be changed with the new supportFile option in your cypress.json. This feature can also be turned off by specifying supportFile: false.
Print DEBUG logs
Print a message to the Command Log.
Print a message to the Cypress Command Log.
Print a message with arguments to the Command Log.
Print all env vars:
Print all existing installed versions of Cypress. The output will be a space delimited list of version numbers.
Print environment variables with proxy (case insensitive) in the name:
Print messages with arguments to the Command Log.
Print the path to the Cypress cache folder.
Prior to issuing any of the commands, we check the current state of the DOM and take some actions to ensure the DOM element is “ready” to receive the action.
Problematic headers are now automatically stripped from remote responses.

Problems logging in through GitHub in the Test Runner have been fixed. The GitHub login window no longer shows the browser support banner and the “Authorize cypress-io” button is no longer disabled. Fixes #1251.
Project ID

Project ID’s and cypress.json are now only generated once you start your Cypress server. Previously they were created initially when you choose the project folder. This now means you won’t have to cleanup excess files if you accidentally select the wrong folder. Additionally you can now use Cypress 100% offline. Previously the GUI would block until the project had an ID but this restriction has been lifted.
Project ID’s can be programmatically set now.
Project analytics
Projects

Projects are either public with their runs being publicly viewable by anyone, or private which restricts their access to only users you’ve invited. All existing projects were set to private by default.

Projects will no longer automatically acquire a projectId when being added. There is now a very explicit opt-in process where you setup your project to record. This should make it much clearer what’s going on behind the scenes.
Projects without an ID now error correctly when running in CI.

Promises
Properly whitelist resource like XHR’s which have query params such as jquery’s {cache: false} option.

Protocol can be omitted from common hosts

Provide record key directly:
Provide the username and password in the auth object. Then all subsequent requests matching the origin you’re testing will have these attached at the network level.
Provider
Providing a “number-string” as in: should("have.length", "1") will no longer throw an error.
Proxied moment onto cy as cy.moment.
Proxied jQuery: $ onto cy as cy.$ and specific class methods: Event, Deferred, ajax, get, getJSON, getScript, post.
Proxies all HTTP / HTTPS traffic.

Proxy Auto-Configuration (PAC) files are not currently supported. If your organization uses a PAC file, contact a network administrator to ask what HTTP proxy you should be using to access the general Internet, then use that proxy with Cypress.
Proxy Configuration

Proxy policies: ProxySettings, ProxyMode, ProxyServerMode, ProxyServer, ProxyPacUrl, ProxyBypassList

Reduced the frequency the app checked for updates. Fixes #713.
Reduced the number of internal Cypress network requests in the “Network Panel” of Dev Tools. Fixes #606.

RegExp arguments are now properly formatted in the Command Log.

Regular Expression
Regular XHR’s can now be aliased and waited on without actually being stubbed by passing {stub: false} to the cy.route().
Release behavior
Reload the browser and see debug messages within the Developer Tools console. You will only see the “cypress:driver” package logs that run in the browser, as you can see below.
Reload the page as if the user clicked ‘Refresh’
Reload the page without using the cache
Reload the page.
Reloads Cypress when one of the watched files changes
Remember because assertions are used to describe a condition of the previous commands - the timeout modification goes on the previous commands not the assertions.
Remember that Cypress commands are async, including .as().
Remember the delay we introduced into our application code that causes the test to time out? We added a 100ms delay before the UI rerenders itself.

Remember to use .only to limit which tests are run: this can be especially useful when you’ve got a lot of tests in a single spec file that you’re constantly editing; consider also splitting your tests into smaller files each dealing with logically related behavior.
Remember, any changes that you make to configuration using this API will only be in effect for the remainder of the tests in the same spec file.
Remember, any changes that you make to environment variables using this API will only be in effect for the remainder of the tests in the same spec file.
Remote: COMMIT_INFO_REMOTE
Remove ‘admin’ from organization
Remove ‘member’ from organization
Remove ‘owner’ from organization
Remove accidental debugger left in uncaught overloads (used only in Dev).
Remove the need to ever do conditional testing.
Removed chai-jQuery and rewrote it from scratch.
Removed Cypress.addParentCommand(), Cypress.addChildCommand(), and Cypress.addDualCommand() in favor of the new custom command interface.
Removed cy.assign, this has been folded into .as().
Removed cy.inspect command.
Removed cy.to.
Removed electron-positioner since it was no longer being used. Addressed in #4502.
Removed fa-refresh icons next to suites and tests until this behavior has been reimplemented due to ID removal.
Removed iframe and link[rel=stylesheet] elements during DOM revert.
Removed method-override. Addressed in #4209.
Removed numElements label on assertions which indicated the number of elements found if > 1. This was annoying and redundant since the inked command already had this number.
Removed progress#2733.
Removed string-to-stream since it was no longer being used. Addressed in #4619.
Removed tar-fs. Addressed in #4148.

Removed {stub: false} option from cy.server() and cy.route(). Cypress will now log a deprecation warning when you use the this option. Removing this option helps simplify the API because now Cypress can figure out whether you really want to stub the route based on whether you’ve provided a response or not. If you have not provided a response, the default behavior will be to not stub. If you do provide a response, Cypress will stub the route.
Removed an extraneous error display from Electron during cypress run about a “transparent titlebar” setting. Fixes #1745.
Removed cy proxy commands: each, map. These didn’t really “fit” into the concept of a command, and with .invoke() or .its() they’re accessible anyway, so nothing is really lost.

Removed factoring in the total time a test has been running when determining when its command timeout. This fixes a bug where commands down he chain would timeout earlier than their specified {timeout: num} option.
Removed memory leaks surrounding Mocha runner.

Removed nested cypress object in the cypress.json. Existing cypress.json files are transparently rewritten on the next server boot, so you can check in the modified cypress.json and all will be well. Fixes #82.
Removed problematic content-security-policy headers
Removed resetting the runnable timeout when a page load event resolves. This prevents an edge case where the next test may show as timed out during cypress run.
Removed sending sinon on every cy.visit().
Removed several aliases from our browser detector. These were not implemented properly and not needed - and thus only caused indirection. Fixes #1023.
Removed several libs that used to handle typing simulation and rewrote typing from scratch.

Removed special logic for Angular which tapped into its digest cycle for queueing commands. This had unpredictable results when there was n interval set, and is now superseded by the new queueing system anyway (which is more performant).
Removed stack traces on AssertionErrors in the console since those come from chai and are basically useless.
Removed support for Cypress.Cookies.get, Cypress.Cookies.set and Cypress.Cookies.remove
Removed support for Cypress.Cookies.get, Cypress.Cookies.set and Cypress.Cookies.remove.
Removed the cookies option from cy.request() because cookies are now always get/set on requests. This option really never made any sense to have. Fixes #320.
Removed the eventually flag in assertions as now this is the default behavior on normal assertions.
Removed the flag --disable-background-networking from the Chrome launch args to fix problems in CI that would throttle XHR callbacks by up to 20-30 seconds. Fixes #1320.
Removed the message about private projects requiring a paid account in the future. There will be a free tier including private projects. Fixes #827.
Removed the word ‘already’ from the Cypress install message in order to be less confusing. Adresses #2754.
Rename the screenshot

Renamed configuration option visitTimeout to pageLoadTimeout. You don’t need to change anything. If you were specifically setting visitTimeout in your cypress.json file it will be transparently rewritten pageLoadTimeout on the next server boot. This option was renamed because now multiple commands cy.visit(), cy.go(), and cy.reload() all depend on this timeout option.
Renamed environmentVariables to env in the Desktop GUI. Fixes #1052.
Renamed onConsole and onRender Command Log options to consoleProps and renderProps. We still support the older property names for backwards compatibility.
Renamed supportFolder to supportFile in cypress.json. We will automatically rename your cypress.json if this property was present on update.
Renamed all remaining old references to eclectus.
Renamed configuration option commandTimeout to defaultCommandTimeout. Cypress will transparently rewrite this if you have it in your cypress.json, so you don’t have to do anything.
Replace a function, record its usage and control its behavior.
Replace a method with a function
Replace a method with a stub
Replace built-in window methods like prompt
Replaced Ruby / Compass with node saas.
Replaced use of new Buffer with Buffer.from. Fixes #2626.
Report per spec
Reporter Options
Reporters
Reporters in CI can now be specified.
Reporting
Repurposed .and() to be an alias of .should() for chainability.
Repurposed requestTimeout to now mean the time we wait for an XHR to be requested. Changed cy.request() to now use responseTimeout configuration value.
Request Body
Request Commands (now page events) have now been renamed to ‘XHR’.
Request Headers
Request Polling
Request a page while disabling auto redirect
Request is not displayed in the Network Tab of Developer Tools
Requesting OSS plan for an org
Requests

Requests that are not stubbed actually reach your server. By not stubbing your responses, you are writing true end-to-end tests. This means you are driving your application the same way a real user would.
Requests that don’t match any routes
Requests that go through cy.visit() or cy.request() are now automatically retried on ENOTFOUND errors. Fixes #4424 and #1755.

Requests that go through cy.visit() or cy.request() are now automatically retried under the hood when the request fails. This more closely reflects Chrome’s default behavior on requests. Addresses #4013, #898 and #1013.
Require Element
Require subject be of type: element.
Require subject be one of the following types: element, document or window

Requires seeding data

Reruns Cypress tests when the back end server restarts

Resolved Configuration
Resolved values will show up in your Settings tab.
Resource
Response Body
Response Headers
Response body when stubbing routes
Response functions
Response headers for stubbed routes

Response headers on XHR stubs will now automatically set their Content-Type based on the stub response. Previously this would always set to the Content-Type to application/json. Now if you force a response to be text or html, the Content-Type response header will be set appropriately.
Response status code when stubbing routes
Restore all overridden native functions. This is automatically called between tests, so should not generally be needed.
Restores
Restyled the tests list.
Retries
Retry cy.wrap() if undefined when followed by .should()
Retry-ability
Return Values
Return a Promise from an asynchronous task
Return early
Return just a single configuration option value
Returning null from a .then() will now change the subject to that. Previously returning null would not cause subject changes.
Returning undefined will not modify the yielded subject
Returning a promise in a custom command while also invoking cy commands now throws. Fixes #435.
Returns JSON containing latest available CDN destinations
Returns you the selector value for a given element as determined by the selector strategy.

Reverted window.location overrides. This broke things in unexpected ways and after further testing would not have worked on Firefox and IE. It’s back to the drawing board (but I have some ideas). Apps using pushState routing are broken again.

Reverted the Chrome argument that disabled RootLayerScrolling which was used to prevent the application under test from “shaking” due to a bug in versions 66 and 67. This workaround inadvertently created a different and much more severe bug in Chrome 68 that would miscalculate pointer coordinates. This led to Cypress giving confusing errors about elements being covered up on action. This is still a bug in Chrome, and is fixed in Canary but has not yet been released to the stable Chrome 68 channel. Nevertheless, removing the RootLayerScrolling flag does fix it. We did several experiments to try to ensure that the “shaking” behavior does not exhibit itself in Chrome 68. We have limited the --disable-blink-features=RootLayerScrolling flag to Chrome 66 and Chrome 67. Fixes #2223 and #2215 and #2037.

Rewrote error message which is displayed when Cypress cannot parse your test / spec file. Now a list of suggestions are given and an external link is provided which further explains how this may happen.
Roadmap
Route
Routes
Routes no longer display as duplicated in between test runs when cy.server() is started prior to a cy.visit() and you cause a full page refresh, which caused all routes to be re-bound.

Rubygem for using cypress.io with Ruby on Rails applications

Run the same test using --browser chrome. The problem might be isolated to the Electron browser.
Running npm install --save-dev cypress will automatically download the CLI + binary.
Running Cypress in Continuous Integration is almost the same as running it locally in your terminal. You generally only need to do two things:
Running Cypress in a linux VM on VirtualBox no longer displays “black screens”.
Running Cypress via cypress run now supports scripts of type="module". Fixes #3696.
Running Experiments
Running a single test will now automatically expand to display its commands.
Running a specific test won’t open/close immediately when starting up (fixes weird flickering effect).
Running an external process (like spinning up a Webdriver instance of another browser like Firefox, Safari, or puppeteer)
Running an external process.
Running build scripts
Running tests

Running tests in Cypress now requires either Chrome, Chromium, or Canary to be installed on your OS environment. We intend to expand support for more browsers in the future, but for now, only these 3 are supported.

Running tests in parallel requires the --record flag be passed. This ensures Cypress can properly collect the data needed to parallelize future runs. This also gives you the full benefit of seeing the results of your parallelized tests in our Dashboard Service. If you have not set up your project to record, check out our setup guide.
Runs
Runs Cypress tests and resolve with all test results. See the Cypress Module API recipe.
Runs Cypress tests to completion. By default will run all tests headlessly in the Electron browser.
Runs linting via ESLint on your spec files as they are loaded and display errors in the console
Runs showing up in the Runs tab now more closely match how they display in the Dashboard. Fixes #2060.
SHA: COMMIT_INFO_SHA

SOCKS proxies are not currently supported. A workaround is to set up an HTTP proxy locally that points to your SOCKS proxy, then using that HTTP proxy with Cypress. Read more about forwarding an HTTP proxy through SOCKS.
Same-origin
Save details about the screenshot
Save the file and switch back over to the Cypress Test Runner. You might notice a few things:
Saves the Cypress test command log as a JSON file if a test fails.
Say you have the following directory structure:
Scaffolded index.js and commands.js have had their content updated to point to the custom commands API.
Scaffolding new projects no longer generates a default.js file.
Scale viewport and fullPage captures
Scaling
Scaling the app should not affect any calculations or behavior of your application (in fact it won’t even know it’s being scaled).
Scopes
Scopes all subsequent cy commands to within this element. Useful when working within a particular group of elements such as a <form>.
Screenshot

Screenshot onAfterScreenshot and onBeforeScreenshot callbacks ar enow invoked for failed tests. They include a testFailure property to distinguish between automatic ones and your own use of cy.screenshot(). Fixes #2040.
Screenshot an element
Screenshot handling
Screenshot names now include their parent titles, and invalid file system characters are scrubbed. Fixes #297.
Screenshot naming follows these rules:
Screenshot thumbnails are also provided with each failure to conveniently provide context.
Screenshots
Screenshots and Videos

Screenshots are now taken during each runnable that fails. Errors in tests will happen there. Errors in hooks will also happen there. Previously a screenshot would only happen after everything (including hooks) ran. Fixes #394
Screenshots are stored in the screenshotsFolder which is set to cypress/screenshots by default.
Screenshots in CI
Screenshots taken with cy.screenshot() on 2x DPI are now taken at the correct full size. Fixes #1857 and #2018.
Scripting 3rd party sites

Scroll the element into view.

Scrollbar styling is no longer hijacked by Cypress.

Sending ‘rerun’ event

Sending {force: true} to Action commands will no longer error out if the element is not visible. Forcing the action to take place now correctly removes all error checking prior to issuing the action and events.
Sequence
Serially click multiple elements
Server
Server instrument now correctly displays the number of responses their corresponding routes have had.
Server sent events now finally work correctly in Cypress. Fixes #1440 and #1111.
Server side rendering
Server side rendering with no asynchronous JavaScript.
Server’s that send Content-Encoding: br no longer cause Cypress to fail due to incorrect decoding. Cypress now strips encodings it cannot accept. Fixes #535.
Server-side redirects are now completely transparently handled and supported.
Servers can now be disabled in the middle of a test. Previously once a server was started all XHR’s would be stubbed.

Setting
Setting NO_PROXY is now respected for HTTPS urls, as it should be. Fixes #4303.
Setting force to true in the options disables checking whether the input is focusable or currently has focus.
Setting a global baseUrl
Setting environment variables in Windows is different depending on if you’re using command prompt or Powershell.
Setting the environment variable CYPRESS_RUN_BINARY overrides where the npm module finds the Cypress binary.

Setting up tests
Setup
Setup route to POST to login
Setup route to error on POST to login
Setup/Teardown code was not properly running on nested Mocha beforehooks which caused the error: The XHR server is unavailable or missing.... Fixes #80 and #86.
Several Capybara finders re-implemented in Cypress to locate UI elements by their text and labels.
Several TypeScript typings were added, updated and fixed. Fixes #1006.
Several color themes for Cypress test runner
Several common viewport presets have been added for convenience
Several improvements to TypeScript typings. Fixes #1881 and #2007 and #1899 and #1902 and #1897 and #1907.
Several instances of memory leaks were plugged up.
